description.text:
I was a victim of the dreaded "Leak down chair".
I flipped it over to get the lay of the land. The cylinder was 1" diameter, so a quick trip to the band saw with a piece of 1" I.D. PVC pipe was in order. I sliced a 2" long piece and then split it. Quick work on the band saw.
Attached with a couple of zip ties. The first was a little too short. I made a 2 1/2" and a 3". Installed the 3" and it seemed just right.
I used 3 zip ties, but didn't cut them, in case I need to snug them up later.
I thought it would need heater hose clamps, but the zip ties are holding OK.
I then drew it up so it can be 3D printed. This part is 1.125" I.D.
Print 2 and install.

Printer Brand:

Printer:

Folgertech Prusa i3

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 - .4

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

The parts that contain the tabs must be printed so that the tabs are at the top, for the stability of the print.
The parts the contain threads (the socket and the lens) should be printed at .2mm so that the threads fit smoothly.
The beacon tower itself can be printed at .4mm.
The lens must be printed with a translucent filament so that the light can shine through. I used a standard PLA "natural" filament and that diffused the light quite nicely.

title: BlinkM MaxM Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This parametric holder for the BlinkM MaxM is designed to replace 2 spacers on a stepper driver on the electronics board of a ToM. As such it requires no extra bolts to hold it in place and gives easy access to the I2C, DC Input and output pins on the BlinkM. Information about the BlinkM MaxM can be found here: http://thingm.com/products/blinkm-maxm.html Note that this isn't designed to have the daughter board (the included 3 led's) attached as this is for projects that are using the BlinkM to drive external LED lighting. This "Thing" is part of a larger project for ToM Mood Lighting, but can also be used on it's own if you need to mount a BlinkM MaxM to your electronics.

• Print (I used 25% fill and 1 Shell).
  • Acteone glue (Abs:Acetone ratio 1:3) the clip in place. Let dry.
  • Press BlinkM in the slot with the DC connector at the top and I2C connector at the bottom. The back of the circuit board should be pointing away from the "spacer" holes.
  • Push the clip over the top to retain the circuit board.
  • Mount the assembly by replacing the 2 spacers on the stepper board.

comments.text: Awesome! Thanks so much Jetty! You know I hate drilling wholes in small PCB's, especially when they have components all over the place and are small....

title: E3D BigBox Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In order to learn how to 3D design and model, I chose Tinkercad due to its ease of use and the availability of lessons and tutorials. These factors are important cause I needed something that I could use to educate our teachers and students without any head-banging frustration. One of my first designs in Tinkercad was this simple calibration tool for the BigBox 3D printer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1344376

I wanted something that was more challenging to create and would look great. So, I began creating this BigBox model in Tinkercad that resembled my own BigBox. My original goal was to complete it and just print a miniature model of my BigBox. Now that I have learned so much over these past few months, I now realize that this model also serves as a great test print of my printer's settings.

Timelapse video of the unsupported Bigbox model print:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/704u685nzcjupku/bigbox_design_2_model.mpg?dl=0

The E3D BigBox contest gave me the motivation to complete my model by adding the requested BigBox team's ideas of real-world use, scalability, and usability with support. I was glad to learn that OpenSCAD wasn't a requirement of the contest, cause that looks like hieroglyphics to me! :-)

Enjoying my BigBox!!!! 700 print hours in 3.5 months!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cQT1htfhOKU

e3D BigBox

Doesn't Matter

25%

FoxSmart Clear PLA 195/70 temps printed without support @ .25mm layer height @ 25% infill

comments.text: Wicked design John!
comments.author: psyvision

comments.text: Thanks dude! I'm finally doing something I really enjoy. I have always had the interest in designing but never had an application for it other than web designing. Being able to create something and then physically hold it and see whether it's a success or not is really gratifying. Thanks for your support along this journey of new learning into the 3D print world. I definitely made the right choice with this BigBox. Love that it's open source and that it just keeps getting better and better from the team and the community members.

title: Bot Window for Cold Environment Printing

description.text:
Build platforms are sensitive to changes in temperature and can affect your prints. After testing a few iterations here is a design that is ready to share; I call it the Bot Window.  I know what your thinking, what a creative and catchy name. :) Ok, truth be told its a simple but effective design that consists of acrylic panels to cover three sides of the bot (left, right and rear (and gets bolted on using left over MBI parts). 
This summer the space I was in had a non-controllable AC where temps were around 55F, yes you read that right, (95F outside at the time). After blocking off air vents to decrease windflow in the room and covering three sizes of the MB (left, rear and right) with cardboard the temps went up to the 65F range. Using a make-shift hood on top (think barn roof) this got me to the 69F+ range and more importantly back to good prints without lifting of edges from rapid cooling.
With drafts from outside and windows in the new space the window panels have taken the chill off the platform (reduced draft) and keeping me in the mid 80's consistently. This design is based off of the MBI TOM MP887 Rev-I design file and will rest on top of the cover plates of the rods running from front to back. 
If you have access to a laser cutter or know someone that has one, this will be quick work. 
Panels were cut courtesy of my friend Angus Hines (www.angushines.com), thanks Angus!

Laser Cut three of the same panels, in my pics you will find 3mm acrylic was used. You will need to drill 4 holes into the wood of your T-O-M for each panel (holes are already in the design). Attach these using M3x16 bolts and nuts that were left over from your MB build. With a Cordless drill and 4 minutes of time you will have all your panels in place. Tips:

  • Acrylic comes with paper on the front/back, when you are ready to mount take the paper off one side only and put a light inside (to help with alignment for drilling holes).

  • The design was made so that the window will sit on top of the plates covering the slide rods (front to back). This will only be used on the rear panel (or front depending on your configuration).

title: Hoover UH70102 Vacuum Cleaner Cord Wrap Bracket

description.text:
I broke the bottom cord bracket on my Hoover vacuum cleaner and decided make a new cord bracket for the vacuum cleaner. It uses the last two existing screw holes at the bottom rear of the vacuum (pictured). Remove the existing screws at the rear bottom and replace it with longer screws. I just used regular lag screws but you can try and test different screw types and they should generally work as long as they're long enough.

The mount holes are made a bit smaller to fit various sized screws, you can just force them through to create a new hole with larger ones.
The bracket is actually very sturdy and better than the factory one using 100% infill.

The bracket is specifically made for this Hoover pet vacuum here but should be moddable to suit different models:
http://hoover.com/products/details/uh70102/t-series-windtunnel-pet-bagless-upright/

Dovetail that can be fixed to a laser module such as http://www.banggood.com/450-500mW-Violet-Laser-Module-With-Holder-For-Mini-Engraving-Machine-p-958363.html to enable it to fit on the 3dpburner2 carriage.

Added a new revision v3 this has a wider base that attaches to the laser module, I had some curling issues printing v2 and this should solve those.
Pencil shaped pencil case with sliding ruler lid. Pencil top eraser type pencil topper. Enjoy.

I designed this tool out of necessity after i started experimenting with tapping holes in printed parts. After years of tapping aluminum and steel parts manually i find that these "T" tools with the wide design is are pretty much idiot proof allowing a lot of torque and precision.

The design consists of three parts: the base, the lock and a M3X20 screw.
the lock slides into the base with a little pressure and clicks into place. The M3 hole needs to be tapped.

I've printed a couple of these and tested them on PLA and ABS parts.

  3. Screw M3 screw through "BASE" part
  4. Start tapping !

comments.text:
Hola Flap, he construido la última pieza del lote, y aparte de que me quedó un poquito arrrugada (posiblemente por ponerle poca sujección) me resultó mucho más grande de lo que debía. En concreto, el diámetro exterior de la BASE (los ladrillos) me sale de 6,2 centímetros, cuando la torre sobre la que encajaría es de 5,4. ¿Estás seguro de la escala, o es que yo he hecho algo MUY MAL? :-)
Sea como sea, enhorabuena por el trabajo. Los detalles son hermosísimos.
comments.author: zephero

comments.text: Hola...no estoy seguro a que pieza e refieres...si es al tejadillo octogonal no tuve problemas para su encaje...pero esta pensado si no me equivoco para un diametro de 5 exinios...osea encajaria sobre una torre circular clasica o sobre una octogonal con piezas pensadas para esa medida diametral http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:880158...

title: The game of 15
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to recreate an old game that reminds me of my childhood, when there were no Playstation, PSP or similar. Can even today be a nice gift for a child "modern" ...
The zip file contains 15 file.stl of the individual numbers, for those who prefer this printing solution.

Print the pieces (without support)
 With a small file, clean up the pieces (especially the numbers)
With a small pliers to remove the supports of the lid (see photo)
 Assemble everything as images
_ Challenge a friend, your children or your grandson in a race to time ;)

description.text:
With the Migbot Prusa i3 being a little messy with the cable management and offering no belt tensioning capabilities, I set out to find a solution.

I really liked the motor mounts, cable chain and belt tensioning of the hephestos, so I created a crossover that fits the Migbots smooth rod and lead screw, while providing mounts for cable chains and belt tensioning like the prusa hephestos.

The rest is plug and play. Simply replace the old parts with the new ones and enjoy fussless cable chain mounts for your x-axis Use the cable chain links from the Prusa Hephestos. Assemble the belt tensioning according to the Hephestos manual.

(note, I do not have the cable chain for the z-axis currently. This is still WIP

Bandage Box

Author: Donald L. Merand

What Is It?

It's a box to hold bandages + antibiotic ointment. It's big enough on the inside to hold a few bandages of various sizes, and a standard tube of ointment. It has a small divider on the inside to keep the tip of the ointment tube separate from the bandages.

It goes in my "going out with the kid" backpack.

3D Printing

I printed mine at 0.3mm layer height in PLA, 60mm/s base speed. It's designed to print fine in the "default" orientation.

Customization

If you want to customize this model, it's available publicly in Onshape right here. The model is entirely parametric, so you can adjust any parameter that suits your fancy.

Connectors for building BBQ skewer structures. Will probably develop these over the summer to explore the strengths of widely used truss systems. Great for bridge building projects without glue (like watching grass grow).

This design differs from the previous (square: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1511419 ) in that the holes do not go all the way through EXCEPT for the center (vertical).

Adjust the tolerance variable to slightly vary the hole sizes. There are still some steps to go to maximize how many fit on the build platform. I'll update after deciding on the ideal sizes.

I print these without rafts since the rafts were sticking to the platform. The easiest way to get these off is to preheat slightly (about 75 C) and pop them off with a spatula or to use an allen wrench in one of the holes to pop it off.

The hardest part is the accurate cutting of the BBQ skewers (we use dykes).

The STL (x28) here take 6 h 20 min to print on a flashforge creator pro.

UPDATE 5/16: Removed the Cenlarged STL. Found a value in between that works well (works out to 3.4mm). The 9x6 STL uses the latest dimensions and makes the most of the build platform (thanks mathgrrl).

remixed_from.author: andrefaggionrp
remixed_from.title: Dual E3D V6 extruder for Migbot Prusa I3 (All Parts)

title: Migbot Prusa i3 Dual E3D v6 mount with dual blower fans

description.text:
I wanted to upgrade my Migbot Prusa to dual extrusion so I took some hints from andrefaggionrp's solution and created my own. I also wanted to mount two blower fans as they (in my opinion) offer better performance than a standard case fan.

Be aware that the dimensions of the clamp holes are pretty tight, so depending on the accuracy of your printer you might need to do some post processing.

To screw the two clamp parts together you need two M3 screws at least 25mm long if you plan on inserting the nut on the other end. Letting the screws bite into the plastic for hold may work as well, but obviously wouldnt be as strong. The thermistor and heater cables can be routed through the hole in the middle, the two outer holes are for the hotend fans.

For mounting the fans I took some wood screws I had laying around. The whole contraption mounts to the standard migbot carriage the same way the old extruder does. Due to height changes, the sensor mount is also slightly shortened.

In order to get a good airflow through both E3D hotends, you can simply mount one of the two hotend fans backwards so it pulls air out rather than push it in.

Keep in mind that this solution has no room for height adjustment so you need two perfectly equal E3Ds or you have to post process the clamp a little bit.

MIgbot Prusa i3

Update 12/16/2016: Minor model changes for even better support of the head. I also found it better to print vertically with a brim and supports, as I had previous issues with the head drooping even with supports on when printing horizontal. YMMV.

Update 08/02/2016: Adjusted length and width of clip. Added more support for the "head" of the clip for improved structural integrity. I strongly recommend removing the adhesive backing from the hook and loop fasteners and super gluing the fasteners to the clips as the adhesive has failed numerously for me especially in the heat. The extensions on the sides of the clip are to allow for more surface area to tape down the clips with duct tape to the metal above the headliner to take off stress on the clip head. Another solution would be to drill small enough holes in your ceiling for zip ties, but I haven't confirmed this as working as duct tape has worked just fine for me, and either way I wont see it once the headliner is on.

title: Lulzbot TAZ 5 Light Kit v4b (with anti-warping fence)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Lulzbot Taz 5 Light Kit

Update: I added the complete BOM below with links to parts on Amazon.

My main goal was to create a light kit that looked factory installed and provided ample light for the print bed. Given the frame of the Taz 5 is black Makerbeam and there just happens to be a laser etched Taz logo plate front and center - this was the my perfect spot to nestle a light kit onto the printer. I designed the light kit to printed as one part that mounted on the Makerbeam frame directly behind the Taz logo plate.

The light kit uses an automotive 12v LED panel from a car dome's light, a rocker switch, a power inlet, and a 12v DC wall wart for power. It is simple, very bright, and runs cool even being powered on for long prints.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The part is designed to be printed as one piece but I uploaded two files here - one with a small anti-warping fence and one without the anit-warping fence. Because my Taz 5 sits directly under an air vent the anti-warping fence provides the best finished Light Kit for my printer. I have printed these all various settings without much effect on the part. The 3D model maybe a little messy (just made quickly on TinkerCAD), however it prints just fine.

Light Kit BOM with links

Since the parts are small you have to buy multiple at a time from Amazon, but these are all useful parts I use on other projects.

Light Kit BOM with links to Amazon for parts:
(1) 3D print for Light Kit body
(1) 12v LED light - On Amazon at: http://amzn.to/1UHf1nR
(1) SPST Rocker switch - On Amazon at: http://amzn.to/1WeWW1M
(1) 5.5mm x 2.1mm Female DC Power Jack - On Amazon at: http://amzn.to/1T3XW5b
(2) M5x60mm hex socket head cap screws - On Amazon at: http://amzn.to/1SWdg1J
(1) 12v 2A+ power supply - On Amazon at: http://amzn.to/24DlZwU
(4) 8" black zip ties - On Amazon at: http://amzn.to/21HzslH

Wire the Light Kit up

I didn't upload detailed build instructions or wiring diagrams, because it is so simple. If anyone needs a diagram or step by step instructions, then just let me know.

The high level overview is the rocker switch pops into the hole on top of the light kit (friction fit). The DC power inlet goes into the hole on the rear side of the light kit and secures with the nut from the inside of the light kit. The LED light sticks to the tray with its own adhesive backing. The LED light wires feed through the opening next to the power inlet (the same opening you used to install the nut on the power inlet with).

The power inlet, LED and switch are all then wired together. However, if anyone needs some guidance here, then just let me know. The installation instructions are also below if you have printed the Light Kit, wired it up and are ready to install on your Lulzbot Taz 5.

Installation

The Light Kit is dead simple to install after it is wired up. Just remove the logo plate and place on the front of the Light Kit and bolt it back on with longer screws.

Light Kit installation:
1). Unscrew the logo plate from the frame.
2). Place the light kit in front of the tee nuts in the makerbeam and replace the logo plate (as the front of the light kit) using 60mm M5 bolts. Black M5 bolts look nicer in my opinion.
3). Run the power supply cord around the makerbeam frame as needed to reach your power outlet and secure with zip ties.

This is a project I embarked on in an attempt to make business cards to hand out to potential employers (I'm a student).

I wanted something different. But more than that, I wanted something that people wouldn't throw away immediately. After pondering a while I thought of how I often lean my phone against a book or something to keep it upright, and thought this could not only be made better but could be made on the sort of scale I was after.

I stumbled on the use of living hinges for phone stands. I tried this briefly but quickly saw that at a credit card size this was unrealistic. After thinking further I realised that just by using a pencil -something almost everyone has at a desk, a flat piece of wood could be given depth, and would work to prop up a phone. I have several (probably over 100!) pencils from Ikea which are about half the length of normal pencils, or in other words just wider than most smartphones.

I designed this stand with these pencils in mind and have found that the stand is incredibly effective. However, the Ikea pencils I used happen to be a fraction smaller than ALL other pencils I can find, so essentially the hole is an odd size.

The DWG files attached are from Autocad, and the CDR is CorelDraw. I have tried laser cutting into 3mm ply and 3mm perspex (clear acrylic). Both work very well. The drawings each have two stands together for cutting - both sides of the stand.

I hope you all have as much fun making them as I did!

This is a mdf made linbin.
Plastic linbins arn't cheap, and you can't just buy a few fold-able cardboard ones. So lasercut them instead!
Designed for 3mm material. I make mine out of mdf!

Sasquatch light switch cover

support - yes, just for screw holes, and the rectangular perimeter around the switch. The rest printed in air, with relatively high fan speed. This was printed with the face up, I haven't experimented with printing face down, because I think the round edges will not come out as nice.
Printed on 8" printbed. (tight fit)

Now you too can get a glimpse of the infamous sasquatch, who roams the northwest forests. This incredibly wise creature has alluded even the best trackers of the world, often times the tracker being the one tracked.. This powerful, stealthy creature can creep in the prone position, move like the wind, and see a wider spectrum than the human eye, where most encounters are not even realized, so intelligent and stealthy that most scientists believe this creature is a myth. This is the King of the Forest.

title: Dino Triceratops 3-layered-animal cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This 2.5D Triceratops is the youngest member of the three layered animal (tla) family, which is kind of strange as it became extinct about 66 million years ago. It is said the Triceratops is one of the most recognizable of all dinosaurs. The design sports a little deviation of the plain layered system as the neck frill is, besides the three horns the most memorable feature.

This build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. After machining it needed a little sanding and simple gluing together.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create (even) smaller versions.

Probably you could make a aluminum version and screw the parts together to get tiny key fob.

You can visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen/Tiere for more animals.
I searched wikipedia for reference pictures and traced the vectors directly using Illustrator. Then I build the model in SketchUp to take a look at the design before wasting material.

author: jasonsolves

title: Dualstrusion Differential - remixed for the lazy

description.text:
Lazy?  Me too.  I thought I'd pass along this layout if you want to print Thing-O-Fun's fantastic differential design in one shot, without having to do all the set up work.   
One color each for left and right extruder, and if you want to print the whole thing monochrome there is an STL for that too.  
One of the files is modified, the original "Side.stl" file has an inner hole diameter that is too narrow, so I made a new matching part with that problem fixed, which saves you the work of reaming out that part after printing.  
Enjoy, and thanks for your great design Thing-O-Fun!

title: Gen4 Interface Firmware
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Request: If you use this firmware, please take the time to click on "I Made One" with a picture of your bot or lcd. This firmware took approx 5 months to write / test and is time I've donated to make the Gen 4 LCD Interface what it should have been. Because this isn't something printable, the best appreciation you can show for this work is to encourage others to use it by keeping it on the Thingiverse front page. Thanks to those who have done this already. This is a major Motherboard firmware upgrade for the Gen 4 LCD Interface, to enable true standalone operation. Supports: ThingOMatic, Cupcake, Reprap and Others. An older video showing some of the features in V1.0: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ONPvZaEAoBQ Video showing an acceleration comparison: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AY6_h80hKOI ** NEW ** Feature list: Requirements: Latest Changes: Note: This is not an official Makerbot firmware release.

comments.text: reading / writing to eeprom is a simple process.  It works or it doesn't.  The only thing I could see causing the write /  read to hang the firmware is if you installed the wrong binary on board.  I.E. 2560 firmware on an Arduino Mega or Mega firmware on a Mega 2560. comments.text:
I was thinking about this one myself :-) There were a few things that factored into decision I ended up at. I'd had a few complaints about the inaccuracy of the estimation on previous builds (despite documenting it), also it was very inaccurate at the beginning (just when you need to know the most). Better than nothing, but not by much as sometime it could over estimate by hours, particularly at the beginning and if using rafts. So I went with what was also the original end goal, a highly accurate estimation at the cost of time (about 1-3% of the build time typically) with an option to skip. But to do this, it requires a pass through the file figuring out how long it will take for all the commands, Mega 2560's are still slow processors unfortunately), I was considering using the old method when "skipped", but the issue was "Confusion to the User" and getting more complaints about the estimation being wrong. However "Completion Percent" as it's not so descriptive, is accurate on Estimation, but if skipped becomes based on the file size (as before), so you can use that. V25 (watch out for it soon), has a "Preheat on Estimate" setting which you can use to Preheat stuff during the estimation. Depending on the size of your build, this could easily mean Estimation is "Zero Cost", or at least not as much of a chunk of the build time anymore. Also, it has a Filament "Trip Odometer", ability to advance through the Build Phase Scroller, Overiding HBP/Tool temperatures in your GCode, ABP printing multiple copies, and "Print Another" for non-ABP users. Finally it will also have (working on it now), Presets ! So changing platforms, ABS -
&
gt; PLA etc. will become a breeze.

comments.text: eried raised a good point about the Lifetime Filament Counter and the maximum number of eeprom write cycles.  The Mega 2560 is rated at 100,000 writes and the counter is written "once" per build or cancelled build and only if filament has been extruded.   100,000 builds is a lot of prints :-)  But if you did print that many, you could always write to the next location.
comments.author: jetty

comments.text: It's also a minimum expectancy...The eeprom in these things have been abused on numerous occasions and they usually die at closer to 11 million writes.  2 Prints a day for 20 years is a lot of writes.
comments.author: jetty

comments.text: I believe the 2560 is 100,000 write/erase cycles for the eeprom locations: http://www.atmel.com/dyn/resources/prod_documents/doc2549.pdfhttp://www.atmel.com/dyn/resou...

comments.text: Re: "but I get little "pulses" every so often on the axis jogs".  This is normal on "Cont" mode.  The firmware didn't used to have any button held down detection capability.  So what happens now is that the Cont is implemented as lots of separate "Long" jogs.  After the Long jog has finished, it checks to see if the same button is held down and if so, issues a Long jog again.  This will appear as pulses depending on the timing, but it doesn't effect anything like accuracy or wear and tear.

comments.text: I think this maybe a general feature and not new firmware related and I noticed this on the original firmware.  You'll notice the extruder will also do this too.  The reason is that the extruder / heated platform signal they're ready before reaching temp, but by the time it gets to printing the first "real" layer, temp is there or pretty close.  I'm guessing there's some logic somewhere in the temperature code to detect when it's reaching the apex of the temp curve.

For example 107/110C because by the time it gets to the actual print, it has got to 110C.   However it seems to be correct that the new firmware is starting earlier (88C/110C) when I just tested.
comments.author: metalman1661

comments.text: This has now been fixed, please download firmware version V21
comments.author: jetty

comments.text: So to clarify further.  The temperature reported in Build and Monitor is the same as before, i.e. no code changes.  The preheat menu sets the temp to the target you select in the preheat menu, but anything you generate from Rep G in Gcode and save to SD Card, or print from RepG will override any temp you've set in Preheat once you start printing.  It maybe that you have the Preheat set to a low temperature and that your are preheating.  In which case, change the preheat temperature to match the temperature you print at, then it will behave more like you'd expect (I'm guessing).

comments.text: You can't unless you compile yourself a custom firmware.  The Jogging code is the original code and has hard coded speeds in.  The extruder code I added however has a "Set RPM" function that controls the speed and remembers it in Eeprom.  If makerbot adopt this firmware, I would add a similar approach for X/Y/Z  Jogs.  Homing need to be slower as the best accuracy is when it's slow.

comments.text: I thought about these at the time, and this was my reasoning.  Regarding the cancel aka "Abort Print", the reasoning it defaults to "Pause" was to do no harm in case someone hits the wrong key, as now the "Cancel" button is overloaded with Pause, Abort Print and Cancel (Do Nothing).  I.E. before when hitting the cancel button, the intent was to abort, now it could be pause or abort.  I originally had it the other way around, and I'd accidentally aborted prints I didn't want to when button happy.

title: Hydroponics 2 Liter Bottle Rim with Sprinkler

description.text:
Here is a Hydroponics bottle rim that I've been working on. takes 4 zip ties to fasten it to the bottle, and has 6 small holes to water your plants. be very careful with the inlet nozzle, if it breaks you'll have to print an other one. I run three of these with the smallest pump I could find at harbor freight ($8). I've been playing with the diameter of the water holes and how many of them. I think i finally got it right so that a 3/16" piece of tubing can drain the bottle fast enough. MAKE SURE to print these at 100% infill! also only print these in ABS because of the strength of the inlet nozzle and ABS tends to leak water less. Please post your makes, this has been something I've been working on for a few weeks now.

Material: ABS
Infill: 100%
Print Orientation: Upside down
Support : 20% Grid at 90 degrees, touching base-plate only

Follow these, and you will have great success!

author: tibuck

description.text:
This is a winglet air deflector for a Vision-X Light bar. It eliminates the noise that is made by the light bar attached to your vehicle.

I had a 50" light bar attached to the front of my Jeep above the windshield. The wind over the light caused a loud harmonic heard inside the vehicle. The winglet eliminates the sound.

The wing simply clips onto the top of the light bar. To cover the entire length of the bar you will have to print it in several sections.

It's a pretty simple pill dispenser, 7 cells with a lid that opens each cell at a time.
The cells are pretty big and from experience should be able to contain an above average amount of pills.
There's also an eighth stop that leaves all the cells closed.

The design consists of two parts - the base and the top.
The top slides into the base with a little pressure and clicks into place.

I've been using it for a few weeks now and it seems to be working great.

print_settings.Notes:: I opted for a shell thickness of 1mm. A lower infill may also work but I wanted the stand fairly rigid.

description.text:
All the spool stands I could find here cater for the ever popular 608 bearings. I had a hand full of 6000RS bearings just begging to be put to use, hence my contribution to the ever growing pool of spool stand thingies :)

By no means unique this thingy borrows from some of the existing designs around. I wanted it as simple as possible, using the least amount of additional hardware, so you'll only require the following:

4 off M6x30 hex head bolts and nuts (I used some nylon bolts I had)
4 off 6000RS bearings - 26mm OD x 10mm ID x 8mm wide
2 prints each of the Spool Stand Outer and Inner stl's

Assembly is straight forward (I would hope :-P ).

Any bearing with a 10mm ID will also work, as long as the OD is not much more than 26mm (could be less) as you need some depth for your spool flange to prevent your spool climbing out and wandering off. The current setup has 7mm depth which I have found ample.

If your bearing is narrower than 7mm you may need to trim the centre bearing carriers/posts that are inserted either end of the bearing, as I designed it with 1mm internal clearance on an 8mm wide bearing. The small inner flanges allows enough clearance between the bearing and the sides but is also small enough to prevent any possibility of your filament wedging in where it is not supposed to. It also serves as the seating area for the bearing inner race.

Please share if you do print :-)

RepRap

Printer:

title: Tower of Mystique Dragon Head remix

description.text: This is a remix of the dragon head from the excellent Tower of Mystique dice tower. The original is 185Mb, this is about 10% of that file size without losing detail. I imported the original into MeshLab, removed duplicate faces and vertices, and then ran Quadric Edge Collapse Decimation. That took it from 2.29 million vertices and 765K faces to 191K vertices and 382K faces. I haven't tried reducing it even further but I'd bet you could reduce the file size even more without losing detail.

comments.text: This is excellent. Thank you for sharing.

remixed_from.author: sfernald
remixed_from.title: Threaded Filament Dust filter for your Rep 1,2 & 2X---keep your filament clean

description.text:
Adapted from the Filament filters of both CreativeTools & sfernald. Just like the previous designs this uses a sponge to wipe dust and debris from the filament just before it enters the extruder. Major Update!! (03-05-2015)
  • Filter is now universal with multiple connection ends, Mix and match one male and one female to create the filter that works for you. Works with 3mm or 1.75mm filament!
  • Improved threads have less engagement and more clearance to work more reliably, without requiring as much accuracy in printing.
  • Male end has a much larger surface to grab than before and texture has been added to both pieces to help open and close.
  • Hole in 1.75mm connector has been enlarged to try to prevent the need to drill after printing.
  • Still prints without the need of supports.
    • Connections available
  • Male 1.75mm Filament - for attaching directly to extruder or other hole
  • Male 3mm Filament - for attaching directly to extruder or other hole
  • Tube Connector - for attaching to ends of tubing or spicing inline with a tube.
  • Flat - for simple filters unconnected & just placed on filament.

Recommend printing with a layer height of .15mm or less, with 30% infill or more.  
The hole in the male end 1.75mm tends to close up if printed too fast or without enough cooling.  Hole is modeled @ 2.5 mm.  If filament does not fit simply ream with a 2mm or 5/64" drill bit.  Printing 2, or something else that is at least as tall, at the same time also will help.  This allows previous layers to cool before building new ones.  
Original file still available for anyone that still wants it...

comments.text: I bought some filament from MicroCenter ($14.99/1kg) and one of the rolls had a bunch of tiny black shavings.  I used this with a cotton ball instead.  It cleaned the filament perfectly.  The cotton ball was dirty as heck with only about 1/4 spool used.  No clogs, perfect prints.  I have now printed one of these for every spool I have and instead of putting on the extruder side of the tube, I put it between the spool and the tube (i have a MB 5th gen).  When I change spools, I just leave it on the spool ready for the next print and it keeps the tube from getting dirty in process.  It also is nice in that my filament doesn't get tangled between filament swaps.  Thank you for the design.

comments.text:
I am having serious trouble getting this one to print (ABS, recommended settings from instructions). First it would warp for the first 3-5mm's or the larger part wouldn't stick to the bed and would screw the print up.
I did some minor temperature tweaks but now the external threads are warping all over (internals don't look great either).
I finally went into the Gcode and altered the bed temp. I started at 110C bed temp then about 3-4 layers in (at Z0.38) I added a M109 code line to reduce the temp to 100C. That helped to keep the base stuck but also reduce the warping but not eliminate it. I have also reduced the extruder temp 5 degrees. Better but not like I want it.
comments.author: Sandsman

comments.text:
It could be alot of things. What is your build surface (kapton, painters tape, glass, etc)? What are your fans set for? What temperature is your extruder set for? Is your printer enclosed? Is the bed leveled well? Is it set at the correct distance from the nozzle? Did you try using a raft?
Your profile lists a Replicator 2, I thought that did not have a heated bed. Are you successfully printing other parts in ABS? If you have better luck with PLA, why not just print it in PLA? There is no reason it needs to be ABS.
You may be better off asking this question in a forum dedicated to the printer you are using...
comments.author: Sandsman

Kapton tape
Haven't even thought to check fan settings
Extruders at 230 (tried 225 too)
Enclosed
As leveled as I thought was perfect.
The distance seems right, creates a decent base

I designed this filter after being unhappy with couple of other filters posted here.
The bottom part mounts to the side of the printer right under extruder. Top part can be put in place and removed with no screws. There is no need to unload filament when installing this filter.

Cut out 2 pieces of foam and insert them into each of 2 pieces. Put several drops of mineral oil on the foam, pass the filament through and push top piece into the bottom.

NOTE: Attached STL files are for custom extruder published here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1133248 For the original extruder you may need to adjust the location of the hole for the filament.

title: GoPro Hero4 Protective Shell and Angle Mount

description.text:
GoPro Hero 4 protective shell with and without lens protector along with 0 degree, 15 degree, & 30 degree angle mounts. Intended for 250 size quad FPV racer. I made it after my brand new GoPro fell from 200 feet and cracked the lcd glass.

Printing notes: print with the top side of the shell down. Remove support from front LCD window.

Edit: Revised 30 degree mount so it won't tip over.

Edit 2: Added a strap retainer add-on for 15 degree angle. Added a 15 degree shell with integrated strap retainer. Added a revised and more stable 15 degree base.

I have been making multi-panel lights from LED chips and wanted a diffuser that could be placed over the electronics to soften the light. The shell can be resized as needed and has a small ballast across the bottom to hold the unit in place along with gaps for air circulation around the LED source. This will have to be printed in either a translucent or clear filament. The V2 version has a hole in the center of the ballast to channel wires through.
